etymologies: Old English ǣgther, contracted form of ǣg(e)hwæther, of Germanic origin; ultimately related to aye and whether

notes.text: In good English writing style, it is important that either and or are correctly placed so that the structures following each word balance and mirror each other. Thus, it is correct to say either I'll accompany you, or I'll wait here. The two expressed choices are parallel, as each includes the subject and its verb phrase: I'll accompany you; I'll wait here. It would be incorrect to say either I'll accompany you or John because the first choice includes the subject and its verb phrase, but the second choice is just an object: I'll accompany you; John. A corrected version could be I'll accompany either you or John (now the choices are parallel, as each is just the object: you; John)

definitions: used before the first of two (or occasionally more) alternatives that are being specified (the other being introduced by “or”)

examples.text: either I'll accompany you to your room, or I'll wait here
available in either black or white

definitions: used to indicate a similarity or link with a statement just made

examples.text: You don't like him, do you? I don't either
it won't do any harm, but won't really help either

shortDefinitions: indicating similarity or link with earlier statement

examples.text: I was too tired to go. And I couldn't have paid my way, either

notes.text: In good English writing style, it is important that either and or are correctly placed so that the structures following each word balance and mirror each other. Thus, it is correct to say either I'll accompany you, or I'll wait here. The two expressed choices are parallel, as each includes the subject and its verb phrase: I'll accompany you; I'll wait here. It would be incorrect to say either I'll accompany you or John because the first choice includes the subject and its verb phrase, but the second choice is just an object: I'll accompany you; John. A corrected version could be I'll accompany either you or John (now the choices are parallel, as each is just the object: you; John)

definitions: one or the other of two people or things

examples.text: there were no children of either marriage
they have a mortgage that will be repaid if either of them dies

shortDefinitions: one or other of two people or things

examples.text: the road was straight with fields of grass on either side
